Description: Body sherd (mended from four fragments) of Chian black-figured Komast pottery chalice; white slip; interior: glazed streaky black with lotus bud in added red with added white outline and two white bands; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of a bearded male figurebending forward to left, probably a komast (capped head, shoulders and arms remaining; red on cap).
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Lemos places this sherd in Group E of the Black Figure Komast chalices. The chalices in this group do not contain any filling ornament, details of the komasts are rendered very simply and inner decoration is basic.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 172, p. 328, no. 1536, pl. 197)
CVA Oxford II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain 9 Oxford fasicule 2 (p. 83, no. 53a, pl. V)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.1297) (phase 2)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
